newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft working to fix bug in Internet browser.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft working to fix bug in Internet browser.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. is working to fix a newly discovered bug in its Internet Explorer browser that could allow users to unknowingly download destructive programs, company officials said on Monday.
Paul Balle, a Microsoft product manager, said developers were testing a software patch that would be posted onto the company's Web site within 48 hours and possibly much sooner.
"We recognize the severity of the issue and are working to resolve the problem," Balle said.

The problem was discovered by Paul Greene, a junior at Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts, who was posting documents onto a Web site when he accidentally created a Windows 95 "shortcut."

After some experimentation he and fellow-students discovered that a Webmaster could take advantage of the bug to evade security features of the browser and download damaging programs onto the user's hard drive.
The transfer could happen in the background or so quickly that the user might not even be aware of it, said Brian Morin, one of the Worcester students.
The flaw affects version 3.0 of the browser for the Windows 95 or Windows NT platforms.
Netscape Communications Corp.'s rival Navigator browser gives users a chance to abort the download, Morin said.

Microsoft's Balle pointed out that since Internet Explorer 3.0 became available nearly a year ago, millions of people have used the product without coming across the security flaw, which the students published onto their Web site.
"We haven't heard any other reports of this type of thing," Balle said.
